reviewText: No one could possibly have been more perfectly cast for this movie than legendary Italian actress Claudia Cardinale who  flawlessly executes her role as the proverbial passive-aggressive, guilt-inducing mother of Antonin Stahley (Malik).  Her tenacity is portrayed by the "string" wrapped around him every time he feels the brunt of his mother's interference in his life, particularly after he falls in love with her groundskeeper,Bilal.The process of Malik's coming out, especially against the backdrop of the Muslim culture and values, evolves like a fairy tale romance.  Bilal's  masculine beauty and charm, his humility stemming from his subservient position, and the tenderness and passion he ultimately shares with Malik when they consummate their love all make for a beautiful love story.  Malik's Mom, Sara (Cardinale) finds the young men in bed together.  The follow-up is priceless.The acting here is irreproachable, and the production values and cinematography superb. I enjoyed the soundtrack tremendously, especially diva Patty Pravo's rendition of "La Bambola".I recommend this 5 star gem with no reservations.
summary: Excellent Acting and Production Values and a Beautiful Love Story  (French and Arabic w/English Subtitles)

reviewText: This film has all the elements of an excellent rom-com: star crossed lovers, meddlesome relatives, quirky friends, a wedding, a funeral, flash backs, old traditions vs. new mores, and a fascinating location with beautiful scenery.  I learned a lot about Tunisian culture and nature in addition to all the romance.  And Claudia Cardinale the mother was outstanding -- it is so great to see her lively and fierce, just like she was in her youth when she was one of the most beautiful women in films.  Tre magnifique!  The scene where they wake up to find her staring at them made me laugh so hard I fell off the couch. OMG is right.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When it was over I couldn't be sure I liked what I just saw, but I know I did not dislike it either. Other comments that there are editing problems is true. There are just some questionable editing choices that leave you baffled about what just happened and how it plays into the thread (pun intended) of the story. I wish subtitles could have indicated plays on language as the speaking of French and Arabic seemed to be a storytelling device that was completely lost in translation.The idea of the string is clever; it took a minute to catch on, but by the last third of the film has been almost overused.The theme of homosexualty in the Arabic community is an issue but very underplayed. The main theme came across instead to be a troubled parent & child relationship that could play the same without the arabic cultural issue.Things happen a bit too conveniently, but to avoid spoiling the story I won't expand farther. The acting is unconvincing through out, though it could actually be the poor editing that wipes out the actors' thread of character continuity. In an odd way it's almost as if the characters don't seem to have the continuity of story events impressed upon them from scene to scene. (Save the lead who manages, but is very close to portraying an unsympathetic melodramatic.)

reviewText: The passion and chemistry between the two men is so believable and strong that it makes 90% of it's competition fizzle out to nothing but teen angst soap operas!  You can feel the sexual tension in the air and the actors are handsome and natural (not stereotypes).  The man playing the handyman is extremely attractive and charismatic.  Only towards the end of the movie does it turn saccharine and lose some of its momentum.  Nonetheless, compared to artsy trash like "Broken Sky", this film is a masterpiece!

reviewText: It is a very nice movie. It puts together different aspects of the gay live in a community full of cultural/ethnic values and prejudices. It shows how difficult it is to born in a Muslim country and at the same time be a gay person. This movie is very much what is happening right now in many Islamic and Hindu countries where gay people are obliged to get marry in order to preserve the family's tradition.
summary: Puts together many aspects of the gay life

reviewText: What and why is this damn string present throughout? Did I miss it? Is it real or just making a statement about a overbearing, to put it mildly, mother and her inability to let go of this poor son.  Evidently, he does not have the strength to cut it since he is just really pissed off that it is there. So angry that all he does is appear confused as to why it is there at all. Neither do I get why a grown man has this string coming out at various times in the whole movie from the back of his pants. Usually, I am a lover of the truly symbolic issue in a movie but I guess I missed it and was too interested in the class evident love story than, the strings presence or purpose. The love story between two lovers is nice and if they had more of that, I think, I would have liked this movie more. However, because the actors are good it made me stick to this movie and seek more meaning. The best I could do is find it O.K.yet it could have been a fine film if the better of the two story lines were better used.

reviewText: This was a nice film.  I read some of the other reviews and thought I'd give it a try and I'm glad I did.  I half expected more negativity from the Muslim perspective, and was surprised to see that wasn't the focus of the film.  It was a tad choppy at certain parts, but overall pretty well done.  I'm not sure if I would use the words "torridly romantic" as is used in the description....... I would call it a nice gay romance story with a happy ending.  Who doesn't like that?  Worth the 3 bucks to rent it.

reviewText: Bound by motherly love, interested in a man that is below him on a social scale, the man is imprisoned by who he is and what he really wants to be.  It's a roller coaster ride of emotion.  One moment you're applauding him and the next, you are actually hating the man for his coldness.  Yet, let it be said that truth does find its way through the muddle and pain of a tortured soul.  Let's face it.  Without truth, why exist?  Interesting movie.  The filming was rather poor, but the story kept my interest.
summary: Odd Movie, But You Can't Stop Watching
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a rule I enjoy Gay films, and I watch foreign Gay film to understand the issues that exist for the Gay community in other countries. I really could not quite find the issue here. It seemed that his mother never really wanted her son to grow up, hence he was always tethered to her by this string? As a mother one always thinks of a son as your baby boy, and do we ever really want them to grow up and leave us? But they do grow up and in the end we want them to be able to grow up. Perhaps the thought was it was the mother's fault that her son preferred the intimate company of men. (that is just plain silly) People fall in love with who they are attracted to. In the end the Gay part of this film didn't make sense to me, why include it when mothers can affect their straight sons with ill effect. I do not recommend this movie unless you are in a truly deep philosophical mood.

reviewText: The young male lovers are beautiful and sexy.  In fact this movie is full of sexy hot Arab guys on the make. Claudia Cardinale is fabulous though her teeth are "horreeblay"! The sets and scenery are often breathtaking. I especially like the close up view of the street life and male hustlers in Tunis. Too bad the story is shallow, disjointed, and unconvincing. The scenes hop around a lot and the characters are undeveloped leaving the viewer frustrated and confused while the neat happy ending is a bit too contrived.

reviewText: Enjoyable piece of fluff.  What is there not to like:  gorgeous scenery, gorgeous people (including the still ravishing Claudia Cardinale), happy ending with everyone being open-minded and accepting and loving.  Just like Hollywood used to make them.  Not a maladjusted, self-destructive person in sight.  And that's A-OK with me.But to view this film as an exploration of "class, cultural and sexual differences", as the DVD case describes it, is ludicrous.  Malik and Bilal are going to form political parties?  They formed parties all right, but the kind where there's lots of champagne and dancing and everyone is having a good time.  "The String" is no more grounded in reality than an Astaire/Rogers movie had anything to do with the Great Depression.Cardinale and Salim Kechiouche are great.  Antonin Stahly is rather stiff, and comes across more as a whiny, spoiled child than as a psychologically damaged man.  (And what is it about the string?  Apron strings maybe?)  Everything about the movie--photography, actors, music--was beautiful.Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed it for what it is.  It is refreshing that perhaps gay films have reached the point where they can emulate old-fashioned Hollywood romance.  Not a position to be sneezed at.
summary: Just like Hollywood used to make 'em

reviewText: Someone  wrote "It was an OK gay flick, but not a great one." This is the mentality that makes me crazy: all the porn-heads who insist upon ghettoizing any film with any homoerotic content whatsoever as "gay." True, like the hammer that can only see nails, if you are a fan of soft-core guy-on-guy action, this movie was o.k. at best. If, however, you care about things like subtle undertones, an intrinsically coherent story, good acting and gorgeous photography, this is one very good film. Long-ago sex pot Claudia Cardinale has aged well into that manipulating chienne from hell who sends good gay boys everywhere straight to their shrink's office. Because the movie is Tunisian and sensitive to contemporary Arab attitudes toward same-gender relationships, The String (it's a pun on "the son" in French) rises to the status of very, very good film. If, however, eye candy is your sole hunger, the men here are indeed very beautiful, but that is far from the filmmaker's sole preoccupation, and true, you'd be better satisfied elsewhere. Have a nice trip, but absolutely do stay out of the deep end until you are a little more grown up. TEKNOZEN 2vii11
summary: This is a Tunisian film and it's terrific

reviewText: The String (Le Fil) is a `gay drama'. It tells the story of thirty year old Malik, played by Antonin Stahly, when he returns to the Colonial home of his mother (Claudia Cardinale -Italian icon etc). All she wants is to see him settle down and marry.She employs a number of people including a handyman, played by Salim Kechiouche `Le Clan, `Full Speed). They take a shine to each other and start a secret relationship. Not only do we have the social difference of rich and poor but also the societal and religious Christian and Muslim) pressures as this is set in Tunisia.These issues are all explored and there are some genuinely touching scenes. It is beautifully shot, acted and directed. One thing that bothered me was the actual `string' referenced in the title, it is obviously a metaphor, but they actually use a real one attached to Malik at certain points, to emphasise how his family are holding on to him. Whilst this may be seen a stylistic genius, I found it to be more of an alienation device. That said it did not detract too highly from my enjoyment.I do not want to give any plot spoilers, but this was not all that challenging, more of a gentle love story with some spanners thrown in at certain junctures.  In French and Arabic with subtitles (which are not literal at least in the French, in some parts), this has a run time of 90 mins, perfect for the European market.
summary: Nice film, but not very challenging
Title: N/A
